title: How to Set up a Movie Camera System for LittleBigPlanet 2

steps.headline: Create your set and your props.
steps.description: Be sure to make every detail count. Stamps and decorations are a good way to add details. You can also make sure all of the objects are shaped just right using the corner editing tool.

steps.headline: Program your Sackbots so that they interact with the set just the way you want.
steps.description: This also means changing their expressions at just the right time and moving their arms just right. If the Sackbots interact with each other, you might want to mark the exact spot where they're supposed to be with a sticker.

steps.headline: Use timers to time any explosions, lighting changes, ect.
steps.description: just right. Timers are probably one of the most useful tools since you can put your movie down into a sequence of just renege of a second.

steps.headline: Use magic mouths with timers attached to them to add dialogue to your movie.
steps.description: If you have a PS3 microphone then you can also record your own voice.

steps.headline: Once all of the timing is just right, attach a microchip to a block of dark matter that is out of the scene.
Put the desired number movie cameras on the microchip's circuit board.
steps.description: Each camera will be a cutscene.

steps.headline: Now set each camera's angle just right so that it shows everything and only what you want to be seen in the movie.
steps.description: This just makes your movie more enjoyable.

steps.headline: Set each camera's timing so that it shows everything you want it to without cutting anything out.
steps.description: Be sure the dialogue is timed so that it shows within the camera's time, too.

steps.headline: Connect each camera's output to the camera you want to show next until the end.
Now put the starting gate on a scoreboard far away from the set.
steps.description: Now put a user-activated switch on the start gate and set its trigger radius so it completely covers the entrance.

steps.headline: Lastly, connect the user activated switch's output to the first camera.
steps.description: Now test it all out by switching to play mode!

text: Create your set and your props. Be sure to make every detail count. Stamps and decorations are a good way to add details. You can also make sure all of the objects are shaped just right using the corner editing tool. Program your Sackbots so that they interact with the set just the way you want. This also means changing their expressions at just the right time and moving their arms just right. If the Sackbots interact with each other, you might want to mark the exact spot where they're supposed to be with a sticker. Use timers to time any explosions, lighting changes, ect. just right. Timers are probably one of the most useful tools since you can put your movie down into a sequence of just renege of a second. Use magic mouths with timers attached to them to add dialogue to your movie. If you have a PS3 microphone then you can also record your own voice. Once all of the timing is just right, attach a microchip to a block of dark matter that is out of the scene.  Put the desired number movie cameras on the microchip's circuit board. Each camera will be a cutscene. Now set each camera's angle just right so that it shows everything and only what you want to be seen in the movie. This just makes your movie more enjoyable. Set each camera's timing so that it shows everything you want it to without cutting anything out. Be sure the dialogue is timed so that it shows within the camera's time, too. Connect each camera's output to the camera you want to show next until the end.  Now put the starting gate on a scoreboard far away from the set. Now put a user-activated switch on the start gate and set its trigger radius so it completely covers the entrance. Lastly, connect the user activated switch's output to the first camera. Now test it all out by switching to play mode!
